page.title: 16LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Stanhoe derives its name from 'stony ridge.' The word stony may come from the large numbers of Neolithic worked flints which have been discovered over the past thirty years by an interested farm worker. A mile to the east of the village is an unmade road now known to be Roman in origin. This crosses another probably Roman road within the area surveyed. The east-west road is no longer complete bus was once a pilgrimage route to the shrine at Walsingham. Cross Lane, once called Petergate, is named from the core of a cross which once stood at its north end as a marker. Another stood at its south end and between them a small chapel, St. Peter's on a site now partially built on. The street names have all changed, Deepdale is now Station Road, Northgate to Docking Road and so on.
